comment.author: 38896199@N06
comment._content: It was a british plane going by the partial registration, the plane itself looks a little rough around the edges. great picture!

comment.author: 47044499@N03
comment._content: That was indeed a brave mission.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/int0lerant] Yes, a British plane. Apparently McIntosh had financial backing from William B. Leeds (American millionaire). McIntosh flew over to Baldonnel from England at the end of August. He and Fitzmaurice worked on the plane, had test flights and basically waited for good weather...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/int0lerant] Was indeed a GB registered plane. Full rego was G-EBTS. Seemingly it was later involved in another record attempt to India.

comment.author: 55597723@N02
comment._content: Nice photo. Three handsome gentlemen. They were brave for trying.

comment.author: 75421485@N08
comment._content: This is actually just prior to their take-off on September 16th 1927. Captain McIntosh is in the cockpit. The other two are probably ground crew.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75421485@N08] Thanks, Bob! Great help to know that this was McIntosh.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 55082702@N02
comment._content: Built by Fokker in Netherlands This plane was renamed The Spider and flew several (England to Cape Town, England to India) records with Capt CD Barnard as pilot with The Flying Duchess the Duchess of Bedford as passenger. It was also used in an aerial circus in England and India, ended being broken up in India after a long and colourful career.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
